oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Confederate Souvenir
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Patent medicines; Pamphlets; Leaflets; Government officials; Advertising; Promotional materials
Davis, Jefferson, 1808-1889; Stephens, Alexander Hamilton, 1812-1883; Lee, Robert Edward; Jackson, Stonewall, 1824-1863; Atlanta (Ga.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Brochure advertising a patent medicine named "Taylor's Cherokee Remedy." Included in the booklet are line drawings of major Confederate figures, including Jefferson Davis, Robert E. Lee, and Stonewall Jackson. Also included are several poems and short articles.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Taylor's Cherokee Remedy
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Taylor's Cherokee Remedy Of Sweet Gum & Mullein was produced by Dr. James A. Taylor and his father, Walter A. Taylor. They were in business from ca. 1869 to 1884, in Atlanta, Georgia. For a time they were in partnership with John S. Pemberton, 1831-1888, who put out Pemberton's Indian Queen Magic Hair Dye. However, Pemberton is most famous for the invention of the formula for Coca-Cola.
